title: How to Make Lemonade Cake

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C).
steps.description: Coat two 9-inch (22.86-centimeter) cake pans with cooking spray, then set them aside. Regular pans will work better for this than springform pans, especially if you plan on adding a glaze.

steps.headline: Blend the sugar, butter, lemon rind, lemonade concentrate, and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Place the sugar and butter into a large mixing bowl. Add the grated lemon rind, thawed lemonade concentrate, and vanilla extract. Blend everything together on medium speed using a mixer. Keep blending until everything is evenly combined, about 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Gradually add the eggs and egg whites.
steps.description: Add two whole eggs (yolk and whites) into the butter mixture, beating well after each one. Next, add two more egg whites (no yolks), beating after each one you add. Save the second set of yolks for another recipe.

steps.headline: Mix the flour, baking powder, salt, and baking soda separately.
steps.description: Pour the flour into a separate mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, salt, and baking soda. Stir the ingredients together with a whisk.

steps.headline: Alternate between adding the flour mixture and buttermilk into the butter mixture.
steps.description: Beat half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Pour in half of the buttermilk into the butter mixture, and beat it again until well blended. Repeat with the remaining flour and buttermilk.

steps.headline: Pour the batter into the two prepared pans.
steps.description: Try to distribute the batter as evenly as you can between the two pans. Tap the pans against the counter. This will help settle the batter and remove any air bubbles.

steps.headline: Bake the cakes for about 20 minutes.
steps.description: They are ready when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean. If you have a small oven, bake the cakes on two different racks, then switch them halfway through the baking time; this ensures that they bake evenly.

steps.headline: Allow the cakes to cool in their pans for 1 hour.
steps.description: Do not remove them from their pans just yet. This section will teach you how to make a tasty glaze to add between your cake layers. It will result in a moister, tastier cake. If you do not wish to add the glaze, you can skip to the next section.

steps.headline: Level the cakes off as much as you can.
steps.description: Without removing the cakes from the pans, cut off as much as you can from the top, bumpy part of each cake. Don't worry about leveling off the edges of the cake. Save the scraps for making cake balls or eat them.

steps.headline: Poke holes in the cake using a fork.
steps.description: You only need to poke holes in the part that was not cut. This will give the glaze more gaps to sink into.

steps.headline: Prepare your glaze.
steps.description: Pour the powdered sugar into a mixing bowl. Add the thawed lemonade concentrate and water. Stir briskly with a whisk until everything is combined and smooth. Don't worry if the glaze looks liquid-y; this will help the glaze soak into the cakes better.

steps.headline: Pour the glaze over the cakes.
steps.description: Without removing the cakes from their pans, pour the glaze evenly over the top of each one. Don't worry if the glaze pools in the corners.

steps.headline: Cover and chill the cakes.
steps.description: Wrap the top of each cake with plastic wrap. Place the cakes into the fridge for at least 1 hour up to overnight. The frosting will also need to be chilled. Save some time, and prepare the frosting while the cake is chilling, then stick it into the fridge. By the time the frosting is done chilling, the cake will too.

steps.headline: Let the cakes cool off before removing them from the pans.
steps.description: Let the cakes cool off on a wire rack for 10 minutes first. Run a knife around the inside edges of the pans, then invert the cakes onto a flat surface. Let them cool off completely. If you glazed the cakes, you do not need to chill them further; the initial 1 hour or so of chilling is plenty. Simply take them out of the fridge and remove them from their pans.

steps.headline: Beat the first five frosting ingredients.
steps.description: Place the butter into a large mixing bowl. Add the grated lemon rind, thawed lemonade concentrate, vanilla extract, and cream cheese. Beat everything together on high speed until the frosting turns light and fluffy.

steps.headline: Add in the powdered sugar.
steps.description: Beat the frosting on low speed until everything is just blended. Do not over-mix the frosting.

steps.headline: Chill the frosting for 1 hour.
steps.description: This will allow the frosting to firm up and make it easier tp spread.

steps.headline: Spread some frosting on top of the first cake.
steps.description: Place one of the cakes, glazed-side-up on a serving place. Spread about ½ cup (115 grams) of frosting on top of the cake with a butter knife or an angled cake decorating spatula.

steps.headline: Place the second layer on top and finish frosting the cake.
steps.description: Spread some frosting over the top of the cake, then more frosting down the sides. If you have any frosting left over, you can put it into a piping bag fitted with a star-shaped tip, and pipe little stars around the edge of the cake. The second layer should also be placed glazed-side-up on top of the first layer.

steps.headline: Finished.

text: Making the Cake Preheat your oven to 350°F (177°C). Coat two 9-inch (22.86-centimeter) cake pans with cooking spray, then set them aside. Regular pans will work better for this than springform pans, especially if you plan on adding a glaze. Blend the sugar, butter, lemon rind, lemonade concentrate, and vanilla extract. Place the sugar and butter into a large mixing bowl. Add the grated lemon rind, thawed lemonade concentrate, and vanilla extract. Blend everything together on medium speed using a mixer. Keep blending until everything is evenly combined, about 5 minutes. Gradually add the eggs and egg whites. Add two whole eggs (yolk and whites) into the butter mixture, beating well after each one. Next, add two more egg whites (no yolks), beating after each one you add. Save the second set of yolks for another recipe. Mix the flour, baking powder, salt, and baking soda separately. Pour the flour into a separate mixing bowl. Add the baking powder, salt, and baking soda. Stir the ingredients together with a whisk. Alternate between adding the flour mixture and buttermilk into the butter mixture. Beat half of the flour mixture into the butter mixture. Pour in half of the buttermilk into the butter mixture, and beat it again until well blended. Repeat with the remaining flour and buttermilk. Pour the batter into the two prepared pans. Try to distribute the batter as evenly as you can between the two pans. Tap the pans against the counter. This will help settle the batter and remove any air bubbles. Bake the cakes for about 20 minutes. They are ready when a toothpick poked into the center comes out clean. If you have a small oven, bake the cakes on two different racks, then switch them halfway through the baking time; this ensures that they bake evenly. Adding the Glaze Filling Allow the cakes to cool in their pans for 1 hour. Do not remove them from their pans just yet. This section will teach you how to make a tasty glaze to add between your cake layers. It will result in a moister, tastier cake. If you do not wish to add the glaze, you can skip to the next section. Level the cakes off as much as you can. Without removing the cakes from the pans, cut off as much as you can from the top, bumpy part of each cake. Don't worry about leveling off the edges of the cake. Save the scraps for making cake balls or eat them. Poke holes in the cake using a fork. You only need to poke holes in the part that was not cut. This will give the glaze more gaps to sink into. Prepare your glaze. Pour the powdered sugar into a mixing bowl. Add the thawed lemonade concentrate and water. Stir briskly with a whisk until everything is combined and smooth. Don't worry if the glaze looks liquid-y; this will help the glaze soak into the cakes better. Pour the glaze over the cakes. Without removing the cakes from their pans, pour the glaze evenly over the top of each one. Don't worry if the glaze pools in the corners. Cover and chill the cakes. Wrap the top of each cake with plastic wrap. Place the cakes into the fridge for at least 1 hour up to overnight. The frosting will also need to be chilled. Save some time, and prepare the frosting while the cake is chilling, then stick it into the fridge. By the time the frosting is done chilling, the cake will too. Frosting the Cake Let the cakes cool off before removing them from the pans. Let the cakes cool off on a wire rack for 10 minutes first. Run a knife around the inside edges of the pans, then invert the cakes onto a flat surface. Let them cool off completely. If you glazed the cakes, you do not need to chill them further; the initial 1 hour or so of chilling is plenty. Simply take them out of the fridge and remove them from their pans. Beat the first five frosting ingredients. Place the butter into a large mixing bowl. Add the grated lemon rind, thawed lemonade concentrate, vanilla extract, and cream cheese. Beat everything together on high speed until the frosting turns light and fluffy. Add in the powdered sugar. Beat the frosting on low speed until everything is just blended. Do not over-mix the frosting. Chill the frosting for 1 hour. This will allow the frosting to firm up and make it easier tp spread. Spread some frosting on top of the first cake. Place one of the cakes, glazed-side-up on a serving place. Spread about ½ cup (115 grams) of frosting on top of the cake with a butter knife or an angled cake decorating spatula. Place the second layer on top and finish frosting the cake. Spread some frosting over the top of the cake, then more frosting down the sides. If you have any frosting left over, you can put it into a piping bag fitted with a star-shaped tip, and pipe little stars around the edge of the cake. The second layer should also be placed glazed-side-up on top of the first layer. Finished.
